'Pas treatises of Cicero on Old Age and Friendship have long formed a favorite course of reading in many of our eolleges, and are well deserving of such a distinction. They are here presented in a form which, it is hoped‚ will render them still more attract- . ive and useful than they have hitherto proved. To ¹these two treatises are appended the Paradoxa and Somnium Scipionis of the same writer, and the life of Atticus by Cornelius Nepos3 the whole forming a text-hook for Latin recitatione which, it is conceived, will be found well adapted for the younger classes in ¹our collegiate institutions.

The notes have been prepared with a direct view to utility, and to the removing of those difficulties which so often embarrass and discourage the student, and drive him, in the absence os better aide, to the mischievous use of badly-executed translations. The success which has attended the editor’s efforts in in- troducing this system of annotation on the ancient writers is extremely gratifying to him3 nor less grat· ifying is the fact that many, who were loud in their opposition to extended commentaries, are now so con· vinced of the superior advantages of these as to have , adopted them, in several instances, in their own worlrs. It is to be hoped‚ for the sake of American scholar- ship, that the practice will become still more general.
